p.#text: This banquet, for our means, is quite sufficient, with its nuts, beans, figs, a dish of olives, pounded lupines, and a cake.

note.#text: :  A plain earthenware goblet, or cup. Reference has been already made to the Samian pottery. The Proverb in this line is similar to ours, of each "cutting his cloth according to his measure."

p.#text: It better becomes a man who is a slave to bring his expenses within moderation than beyond. Each one to his own station; they, who have wealth at home, drink from cups, goblets, and bowls; we, if we are now drinking from our Samian jug, still build our walls according to our means.

note.#text: :  "Strategum." This is a Greek word, signifying the commander of an army. It was usual with the Greeks, Romans, and Jews, to appoint a master of the feast, who probably gave the toasts, looked to the comforts of the guests, and took care that the quality of the wine was satisfactory. See the second Chapter of , v. 8.

p.#text: But while she who is your mistress and mine is arranging her hair, and bedecking herself, I wish us to have some diversion among ourselves. I appoint you the commander of this feast.

sp.speaker: STICHUS
sp.p: Very aptly does it suggest itself to your mind.

note.#text: :  The absurdities consequent on the unity of place in the Roman Comedy could not possibly be better illustrated than in the present instance. The servants not only carouse in front of their master's house, but absolutely bring out couches to recline upon. Persons of rigid manners, and especially the Cynic philosophers, persisted in retaining the old posture of sitting at meals; to that circumstance reference is here made.

p.#text: Wouldn't we be more suitably entertained like Cynics on benches here, than upon couches?

sp.speaker: STICHUS
sp.p: Aye, but this is far the most pleasant.

sp.speaker: SAGARINUS
sp.p: On which side is each of us to recline by our mistress?

p.#text: Of course you go to the upper place. And, so that you may understand it, I make a division with you on these terms: consider, and take which province you would even like now to take.

sp.speaker: SAGARINUS
sp.p: But what's your meaning about this "province?"

p.#text: Whether you would choose to hold the command over the water or over .

note.#text: :  "Cyathos." The "cyathus" was a cup which contained a fixed and definite measure. It contained but a small quantity, one- twelfth part of a "sextarius," which was not quite an English pint. It seems most probable that the "cyathus" was used for the purpose of ladling the wine out of the bowl, or "cratera," in which it was mixed with water, into the goblets or cups. The question of Sagarinus here seems to apply to the number of "cyathi" of the pure wine which they had been drinking at each goblet-full that they took, as otherwise they would be making but slow inroads on the "cadus," five "cyathi" holding, perhaps, about as much as three of our ordinary wine-glasses. It is not improbable that a portion of the Play is lost here.

p.#text: Over Bacchus, most distinctly. But, in the meantime, general of ours, why stands this goblet here? See how many cups we have drunk.

note.#text: :  These words are in Greek. Eustathius and Athenus say that this Greek song bears reference to the proportions of water that should be mixed with the wine. It seems, however, here to mean that there's "luck in odd numbers" when you are drinking.

p.#text: As many as there are fingers on your hand. The Greek song is, "Drink either your five cups or your three, but not your four."

note.#text: :  The "fons" in this case was probably a pitcher of water which they had on the table. Sagarinus seems to recommend him, in mixing, only to take one-tenth part of water. Sober people generally mixed in the proportion of three-fifths water and two-fifths wine.

p.#text: . I pledge you. Do you take for yourself the tenth part from the fountain, if you are wise. Here's luck to you, luck to us; here's luck to thee, luck to me; luck to our Stephanium as well.
'Tis bravely done. I pledge you in a goblet.

note.#text: :  By "pulpamentum" Sagarinus seems to mean some dainty, by way of a relish; at least, Stichus so understands him, as he points to the nuts, beans, figs, lupines, and olives on the table, and tells him that he will get nothing else.

p.#text: Keep your wine; I'd very much like something by way of a relish.

note.#text: :  He probably tells him to take some water if he feels queer, or, in our vernacular, "seedy," from taking too much wine; which he has some reason to suppose, from the other calling for a "pulpamentum." Anchovy toast is an item of our favorite "pulpamenta."

p.#text: If you are not satisfied with what's here, there's nothing else. Take some water.

note.#text: :  He thinks that the  is inclined to shirk his goblet, and to show that he himself is not flagging in spirit, tries to keep him up to the mark.

:  The "Tibicines," "Pipers" or "flute-players," among the Greeks and Romans, were in the habit of playing upon two pipes at the same time. These were perfectly distinct, and were not even, as has been supposed by some, connected by a common mouth-piece. The Romans were particularly fond of this music, and it was introduced both at sacrifices, funerals, and entertainments. See a comical story about the Roman "Tibicines" in the Fasti of , B. 6, l. 670 et seq. From the present specimen they appear to have been merry souls, occupying much the same place as the country fiddlers of modern times.

p.#text: You say right; I care for no dainties. Drink away, ; drink, if you do drink. I' faith, this must be drunk--don't shirk it.  Why flinch at what you see must be done by you? Why don't you drink? Do it, if you are to do it. Take it, I tell you, for the public pays for this. That's not your way to shirk your drink. Take your pipes out of your mouth.

note.#text: :  It is pretty clear, that in his zeal, and to show that there is no flagging in him, Sagarinus has been overdoing it, perhaps helping himself out of his turn; on this, the other threatens to resign his office of master of the ceremonies.

:  "Nulli rei erimus poste." This is the proper reading, which has been restored by the research of Ritschel. It is difficult to say precisely what he alludes to, but most probably he means, "at this rate our supply will soon be exhausted."
:  He says that the "cadus," or earthenware cask, will soon at this rate be capable of being turned upside down without any risk of spilling the wine

p.#text: When he has drunk, either do you mind my rules, or else I'll give up. I don't wish us to drink this straight out; we shall soon be about nothing; for, by my faith, almost all in a moment, the cask might be turned head downwards.

note.#text: :  The head of the serpent is said to swell, or puff out, when it infuriated.

p.#text: . How now? Although you did make a fuss about it, still it didn't hurt you. Come, , when you've done drinking, put back your pipes to your lips; quickly puff out your cheeks, just like a reptile serpent. Come now, Stichus, whichever of the two breaks order, shall be fined a cup.

sp.speaker: STICHUS
sp.p: You propose a good regulation. You ought to have your way, who only ask what's fair.

sp.speaker: SAGARINUS
sp.p: Mind it then; if you offend, I'll forthwith take the forfeit on the spot.

sp.speaker: STICHUS
sp.p: You ask what's quite right and just.

p.#text: . Here's to you first of all.

sp.speaker: STICHUS
sp.p: 'Tis a droll thing this, for two persons, rivals of each other, to be courting, to be drinking from one goblet, and to be kissing one wench. 'Tis worthy of remark this: I am you, you are I; of one accord are we. With one mistress are we both in love; when she's with me, still she's with you; and when she's with you, she's with me as well; neither of us envies the other.

sp.speaker: SAGARINUS
sp.p: Come, come, there's enough of it; I don't want it overdone to weariness. I'd now like some other sport.

sp.speaker: STICHUS
sp.p: Drink on, if you are drinking.

sp.speaker: SAGARINUS
sp.p: There shall be no skulking in me. But, troth, I've had enough of the feast; would but our mistress come here. If she were here, nothing else would be away.

sp.speaker: STICHUS
sp.p: Should you like us to invite our mistress out? She shall give us a dance.

sp.speaker: SAGARINUS
sp.p: I agree.

p.#text: . My sweet one, my lovely one, my pleasing one, Stephanium, do come out of doors to your sweethearts; to me you are quite charming.

sp.speaker: SAGARINUS
sp.p: But to me, indeed, most charming.

sp.speaker: STICHUS
sp.p: Make us jovial fellows more jovial by your assistance and your company. Returning from abroad, we want you, dear little Stephanium, my honey, that is, if our lovingness is pleasing to you, if we are acceptable to you.

div2.stage: Enter STEPHANIUM, from the house of PAMPHILUS.

p.#text: I'll indulge you, my dears; but, so may pretty  favour me, I should have already come out of doors here together with you, had I not been sprucing myself up for you. For such is the way of woman, when she is well washed, made clean, dressed and tricked out, still is she incomplete; and a female who is a courtesan much more quickly acquires dislike for herself by sluttishness than always keeps in favour through neatness.

sp.speaker: STICHUS
sp.p: That's very cleverly said.

p.#text: 'Tis the genuine language of .

sp.speaker: STICHUS
sp.p: Sagarinus.

sp.speaker: SAGARINUS
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: STICHUS
sp.p: I'm in pain all over.

sp.speaker: SAGARINUS
sp.p: All over? So much the more unfortunate you.

sp.speaker: STEPHANIUM
sp.p: Where do I take my place?

sp.speaker: SAGARINUS
sp.p: Wherever you please.

sp.speaker: STEPHANIUM
sp.p: I'd like with both of you, for I love you both.

note.#text: :  It would appear at first sight, that he has some compunctions, and intends to say, "this feast will prove so expensive that all my savings (peculium) will be wasted, and I shall never be able to buy my freedom." There can be little doubt, however, that an, indelicate pun is intended to be concealed under the expression, "vapulat peculium."

p.#text: Whack go my savings. I'm done for; freedom has abandoned this person of mine.
Prithee, do give me room, where I may take my place, if, indeed, I am agreable.  Now I do long to be cozy with you both.

sp.speaker: STICHUS
sp.p: . I'm ruined utterly. What were you saying?

sp.speaker: SAGARINUS
sp.p: Heyday! What's the matter?

p.#text: So may the Gods favour me, it never shall be otherwise this day but that this girl shall have a dance somehow. Come, my love, my sweet, do dance; I'll dance too.

sp.speaker: SAGARINUS
sp.p: I' faith, you shan't that way get the better of me, but what I'll have a bit of enjoyment, too, that way.

p.#text: Well, if I must dance, do you then give the  something to drink.

sp.speaker: STICHUS
sp.p: Aye, and to me.

p.#text: . , you take first: and after that, if you tipple this off, just as has been your wont before to-day, straightway strike up some merry and amorous tune to dance to, by which we may tingle all over from our very finger nails. Pour some water here.

stage.#text: The  stops playing while he drinks the water.

p.#text: Take this, you; toss it off. The drink didn't please him just now; now at last he takes it with less difficulty. Take it, you.  In the meantime, apple of my eye, give me a kiss while he's drinking.

p.stage: She turns away, while he tries to kiss her.
p.#text: Why, it's the way of a common strumpet, for a damsel to give a kiss standing to her sweetheart as he stands.

note.#text: :  She turns away with affected modesty from Sagarinus, who only manages "to steal" a kiss. His rival is pleased at this, and cries out that she only gives it to him as if he was stealing it.

p.#text: Bravo! bravo! that's the way it's given to a thief.

note.#text: :  It is difficult to say what was the exact difference between the "lepida" and the "suavis cantio." The first was, perhaps, a "merry," and the other an "amorous" tune.

p.#text: Come, blow out your cheeks now; something in the amorous way at once. Give us a new tune in return for the old wine.

note.#text: :  The Ionian mode of dancing was graceful and voluptuous. The Sicilians had a dance of this nature in honor of Diana, which they called "the Ionic dance."

p.#text: What person in the Ionian or the ballet line is there that can do anything like that?

note.#text: :  It is difficult to say what is the exact meaning of "versus" or "versus" here. Possibly, it was the name of some particular dance, or it may have merely meant a "turn" or "round," or as we say, "a set," in dancing. Again, it may possibly mean some curious posture, in which Sagarinus was skilled, and in assuming which Stichus could not cope with him. Gesture and grimace formed the main features of the dance with the Romans.

p.#text: If you get the better of me this turn, just challenge me to another.
Just you do it in this fashion.

note.#text: :  "Bab," "Tat," and "Pap," are merely exclamations of the dancers, while inspired with the spirit of the dance; not unlike the shrieks and noises which are frequently made by the dancers of our times, at fairt and other places of public resort, where uproarious enjoyment takes the place of sobriety, and, not unfrequently, of common decency.

p.#text: And you in this fashion.  SAG. O grand!

sp.speaker: STICHUS
sp.p: O fine!

sp.speaker: SAGARINUS
sp.p: O wonderful!

note.#text: :  "Pax." This was the ordinary expression used to signify a pause--"Stop."

p.#text: QUIET!

p.stage: They dance quietly, in the same measure.
p.#text: Now, then, both in the same step.  I challenge all the dancing-masters to dance against me. 'Tis no more possible for there to be enough of this for us than for there to be too much rain for a mushroom.

note.#text: :  They have fairly danced the wine out.

p.#text: Let's away hence in-doors at once now; we've danced long enough for the wine. You, Spectators, give us your applause, and then go home to enjoy yourselves.
